awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Invariant Convolutional Neural Networks through Many Particle Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Large scale computing in engineering and the physical sciences, in addition to new experimental methods, are generating massive amounts of high dimensional distributed data, and interpreting, analyzing, and using this data is a fundamental problem facing science. Machine learning algorithms extract, interpolate, and extrapolate information from these data sets. However, the complexity of modern data requires new algorithmic paradigms that are capable of parsing intricate and subtle patterns across numerous scales. This CAREER award will make significant strides in developing these new machine learning paradigms, focusing on multiscale systems of interacting bodies that are used to model molecules, materials, and drugs, amongst others.

More specifically, this CAREER award will facilitate an integrated scientific and educational program at the interface of mathematics, deep learning, many particle physics and data science. Scientifically, it will develop a mathematical theory of invariant convolutional neural networks based upon (wavelet) scattering transforms, and seek to interpret the mathematical properties of these scattering transforms through the lens of many particle systems. The research will facilitate fast simulations of quantum many particle systems, thus opening new research avenues in quantum chemistry, materials science and drug discovery. Intertwined with these research efforts is a plan to increase the participation of under-represented students in data science. The centerpiece of this part of the project is a data science themed "alternate spring break," meant to introduce undergraduate students to data science research, which will be integrated with existing programs at Michigan State University to maximize impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is on the study of invariant data representation models obtained through “feature representations” that mathematically model convolutional neural networks; we call these mathematical models (wavelet) scattering transforms, which were first introduced by Mallat in 2012. The mathematical properties of these scattering transform models was developed through the lens of many particle physics, both classical and quantum, and related problems. Empirical evaluation was carried out on problems from the fields of quantum chemistry, materials science, sparse signal processing, and generative models.

 Machine learning for many particle systems is an emerging field that is rapidly growing, as it takes hold in chemistry, physics, materials science, and mechanical engineering, amongst other disciplines. However, most applications of machine learning in this context are an empirical endeavor, lacking mathematical rigor that gives insight into numerical results. Similarly, the mathematics of deep learning is becoming an increasingly important topic in machine learning. In this project we pursued a novel path forward by developing mathematical underpinnings of invariant convolutional neural networks as they apply to problems in many particle physics. Utilizing (wavelet) scattering transforms as models for convolutional neural networks, we developed a unifying mathematical theory of machine learning for many particle systems that links together quantum models, sparse signal processing, stochastic signal processing, and statistical mechanics. Fundamental stability results for rigid scattering transforms, previously unstudied, werel also developed. The mathematical innovation necessary for the success of this project is rooted in both pure and applied aspects of harmonic analysis, but also required the novel synthesis of ideas from quantum chemistry, compressive sensing, and stochastic calculus.
